shortDescription: Alternative controller 3D adventure game about loss, connection, and grief where a blow can create change in the world.
longDescription: One of the core player interactions in The Wind and the Wisp is the ability to blow into your microphone — creating wind in the game world and interactacting with the Wisp through. As a Software Engineer R&D on The Wind and the Wisp, my primary responsibility is to architect and build a custom blow detection solution and controller that is modular, portable, and easy to use.

My development process has included a lot of research, experimentation, and iteration. Studying the Digital Signal Processing fundamentals, I read published papers on blow detection, noise filteration, and speech detection and sought out guidance from engineers with more experience in and knowledge of signal processing to develop blow detection solutions. Most of my early prototyping was in Python where I used the numpy, scipy, and matplotlib libraries to filter and visualize data signals. I then ported the solution to C# in Unity using the NWaves .NET DSP Library and have been consistently iterating on it since based on user feedback from playtests and UX researchers.

To ensure the algorithm performs consistently across microphones and devices, I collaborated closely with a UI designer to design and implement the front- and back-end of an in-game blow calibration sequence. As a result, I've been able to develop a solution that enables precise blow detection and filters out noise and speech, reducing false positives and resulting in significant increases in blow detection accuracy.
